44 y M with h/o developmental delay, obesity who presents with fevers,
#) Food impaction - s/p EGD that revealed food in above 14 mm
esophageal stricture. Does have predisposition for food impaction
including h/o GE junction stricture, esophagitis, and hiatal hernia.
Per GI, esophagel stricture does not require further intervention.
- Educate pt regarding chewing food carefully and cutting food into
#) Leukocytosis - WBC elevated to 15.1 without bandemia. No fevers
while in ICU.  With retrocardiac opacity on CXR, concern for CAP vs
aspiration PNA, vs aspiration pneumonitis.   Pt denies any
symptomatology of GI infection or UTI.  He did have several episodes of
emesis prior to admission, however this was likely caused by food
impaction as  he has not had any further episodes. Lactate not
- Continue levofloxacin, flagyl for likely aspiration PNA.
#) Hypoxia - Likely secondary to possible aspiration PNA. Pt also
diffusely wheezy and rhonchorus post EGD.   Pt tends to desat while
sleeping and may have a component of OSA.  Currently on 6 L NC.
- Treating for likely aspiration PNA as above.
Creatinine improved with 1L bolus fluids o/n. Likely due to
prerenal etiology given innumberable episodes of emesis prior to
admission. s/p 1 L IVFs in ED.
#) Tachycardia - Likely [**12-29**] dehydration, anxiety, pain s/p procedure.
Elevated TSH, consider decreasing levothyroxine on
#) Bipolar disorder - Continue depakote, zyprexa, SSRI. Per group home,
pt can become very aggressive and assaultive and often has verbal
outbursts. Group home to provide 1:1 sitter overnight.  If patient
needs additional supervision during the day the group home should be
contact[**Name (NI) **] as they may be able to provide a daytime staff member as
#) Esophagitis - Continue PPI. No active signs of esophagitis on EGD.
#) Crohn's disease - Not active. Continue asacol.

,Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of developmental delay, obesity, and various medical conditions including hypothyroidism, bipolar disorder, Crohn's disease, and esophageal stricture. The patient presents with symptoms of hypoxia, food impaction, cough, and fevers.

The patient underwent an endoscopy that revealed food impaction in an esophageal stricture measuring 14 mm. The patient has a predisposition for food impaction due to a history of gastroesophageal junction stricture, esophagitis, and hiatal hernia. It was determined that the esophageal stricture does not require further intervention, and the patient was educated on proper chewing techniques and cutting food into small pieces before swallowing. The patient will continue taking a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).

The patient also has leukocytosis with a WBC count of 15.1, but without bandemia. There are concerns for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), aspiration pneumonia (AP), or aspiration pneumonitis due to the retrocardiac opacity seen on chest X-ray. The patient denies any gastrointestinal infection or urinary tract infection symptoms, but has had episodes of emesis prior to admission. The patient's lactate levels are not elevated, and pressures are stable. Levofloxacin and Flagyl are being continued for likely aspiration pneumonia. The patient's blood cultures and sputum cultures are pending."

,Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of developmental delay, obesity, and various medical conditions including bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, Crohn's disease, and a hiatal hernia. The patient presents with fevers, cough, and possible food impaction.

The patient underwent an endoscopy that revealed food in an esophageal stricture measuring 14 mm. The gastrointestinal department determined that the esophageal stricture does not require further intervention. The patient was educated on chewing food carefully and cutting it into small pieces before swallowing. He is also to continue taking a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).

The patient has leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15.1, but no fevers while in the ICU. There is concern for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), aspiration pneumonia (AP), or aspiration pneumonitis due to retrocardiac opacity on chest X-ray. The patient denies any symptoms of gastrointestinal infection or urinary tract infection. His lactate levels are not elevated, and pressures are stable.

The patient is being treated with levofloxacin and flagyl for likely aspiration pneumonia. Liver function tests are mildly elevated, and a urinalysis is pending. The patient's fever curve is being trended, and blood cultures are being followed up. A sputum sample for culture is also awaiting.
The patient is experiencing hypoxia, which is likely secondary to possible aspiration pneumonia."

The patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of developmental delay, obesity, and several medical conditions including bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, esophageal stricture, hiatal hernia, Crohn's disease, and possibly food impaction. He presented to the ICU with fevers, cough, and possible food impaction. The patient underwent an endoscopy which revealed food in an esophageal stricture. He also had nasal and urine cultures taken. His vital signs show sinus tachycardia, low blood pressure, and decreased oxygen saturation. The patient's laboratory results indicate leukocytosis, elevated lactate levels, and mildly elevated liver function tests. He is currently receiving IV fluids, antibiotics, and other medications. Potential medical complications include aspiration pneumonia, acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, hypoxia, and dehydration.

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory symptoms and retrocardiac opacity on chest X-ray raise concerns for aspiration pneumonia. He is already receiving appropriate treatment with antibiotics and probiotics.

2. Acute Respiratory Failure (ARF): The patient's low oxygen saturation and respiratory distress may indicate acute respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring and treatment with nebulizers as needed are recommended.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest a possible pre-renal cause of acute kidney injury. Fluid resuscitation with IV fluids has already"

The patient is receiving multiple infusions, including Fentanyl and Midazolam, as well as other medications. Their review of systems is unchanged from admission except for some noted below. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 119/69 mmHg to 141/122 mmHg, respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 90% on a nasal cannula. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient's fluid balance shows a total input of 1,340 mL and output of 325 mL, resulting in a balance of 1,015 mL. They are receiving IV fluids and have received blood products. The patient is also on respiratory support with an oxygen delivery device and has an ABG result of ///28/.
The patient's physical examination reveals that peripheral vascular pulses are not assessed, skin is not assessed, and neurologic responses are also not assessed.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.1 K/uL, hematocrit of 40.9%, platelet count of 223 K/uL, creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL, and glucose level of 116 mg/dL. Other lab values include calcium, magnesium, and phosphate levels.

The patient has been diagnosed with hypoxemia and is receiving ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient's code status and disposition are also documented."

,The patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of developmental delay, obesity, and several medical conditions including bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, esophagitis, Crohn's disease, and food impaction. He presents with fevers, cough, and possible food impaction.

The patient underwent an endoscopy which revealed food in an esophageal stricture. It was determined that the stricture does not require further intervention, but the patient should be educated on carefully chewing food and cutting it into small pieces before swallowing. He should continue taking a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).

The patient also has leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15.1, but without bandemia. There is a concern for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), aspiration pneumonia (PNA), or aspiration pneumonitis due to the retrocardiac opacity seen on the chest X-ray. The patient denies any symptoms of gastrointestinal infection or urinary tract infection, but he did have several episodes of emesis prior to admission. Levofloxacin and Flagyl have been continued for likely aspiration PNA, and follow-up blood cultures, sputum culture, and lactate levels are being monitored.

The patient is experiencing hypoxia, likely secondary to possible aspiration PNA. He is also wheezy and rhonchorus post endoscopy. Oxygen therapy will be weaned as tolerated, and nebulizers will be used as needed.

The patient is a 44-year-old male with developmental delay, esophageal stricture, and several medical conditions including food impaction, pneumonia, hypoxemia, nausea/vomiting, acute renal failure, hypothyroidism, bipolar disorder, and Crohn's disease. He was admitted with food impaction and pneumonia. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) was performed to move the food into his stomach, and he is being continued on proton pump inhibitor (PPI). The pneumonia is believed to be aspiration-related due to the esophageal food impaction. Antimicrobials and MDIs are being continued to treat the pneumonia. The hypoxemia is attributed to the pneumonia, and supplemental oxygen is being administered to maintain SaO2 > 90%. The patient's nausea/vomiting has improved and is now attributed to the food impaction. Acute renal failure is suspected to be pre-renal and the patient is being hydrated with intravenous fluids (IVF). An elevation in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level suggests hypothyroidism, and free T4 will be checked. The patient's bipolar disorder and Crohn's disease are being managed with their respective medications.
1. Respiratory Complications: The patient has hypoxemia due to pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory distress and further respiratory complications if not managed properly.

The patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of developmental delay, esophageal stricture, pneumonia, and multiple medical conditions including bipolar disorder, Crohn's disease, hypothyroidism, and possible acute renal failure. He presented with food impaction and was admitted to the ICU. The patient has been experiencing hypoxemia, nausea, vomiting, and anemia. He is currently on supplemental oxygen, antimicrobials, MDIs, PPI, and other medications for his various conditions. The patient's vital signs are stable, and he is alert and oriented. Physical examination reveals no acute distress, but there are signs of respiratory distress and possible aspiration pneumonia. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin levels, and abnormal thyroid function tests.

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's history of esophageal stricture and food impaction increases the risk of aspiration, leading to pneumonia. This condition can worsen the patient's respiratory status and increase the risk of respiratory failure.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient may have pre-renal acute renal failure due to dehydration or hypotension. This condition can lead to electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload if not promptly treated.
3. Hypothyroidism: The elevated TSH level indicates possible hypothyroidism. If left untreated, this condition can lead to further decline in the patient's overall health and metabolic status.

4. Anemia: The decreasing hemoglobin levels suggest anemia, which can result in decreased oxygen-carrying capacity and tissue hypoxia. The underlying cause of anemia needs to be investigated and managed appropriately.

5. Bipolar Disorder and Crohn's Disease: Although these conditions are not directly life-threatening, they require ongoing management to prevent exacerbations and optimize the patient's quality of life.
6. Possible Seizure Disorder: The patient has a history of seizures related to clozapine use. It is important to monitor for any signs of seizure activity and ensure proper seizure management.

7. Potential Adverse Drug Reactions: Given the patient's multiple medications, there is a possibility of adverse drug reactions or drug interactions. Regular monitoring and medication review are necessary to minimize these risks.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory status, renal function, thyroid function, anemia, and psychiatric conditions. Prompt intervention is crucial to prevent further complications and improve the patient's outcome."

,The patient is a 44-year-old male with developmental delay, esophageal stricture, and pneumonia. The patient was admitted with food impaction and pneumonia. The assessment and plan include the following:

1. Food impaction: The patient underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to move the food into the stomach. No further intervention is required. The patient should continue taking proton pump inhibitor (PPI) medication. It is recommended to check with the gastroenterology service whether the patient requires dilation of the stricture prior to discharge.

2. Pneumonia: The patient likely aspirated food due to esophageal stricture, leading to pneumonia. The patient should continue antimicrobials and MDIs (presumably means ""medication devices"" or ""medical inhalers""). The patient's cough should be encouraged.

3. Hypoxemia: The patient's low oxygen levels are attributed to pneumonia. The patient's supplemental oxygen should be continued, aiming to maintain SaO2 (arterial oxygen saturation) above 90%. The patient's condition should be closely monitored.

4. Nausea/vomiting: The patient initially experienced nausea and vomiting due to food impaction, but these symptoms have now improved. It is believed that severe coughing may have contributed to the vomiting.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient likely has pre-renal acute renal failure. Hydration should be improved.

FOOD IMPACTION -- Esophogeal stricture.   s/p EGD with movement of food
into stomach.  No further intervention.  Continue PPI.  Need to
determine whether requires dilitation of stricture prior to discharge
PNEUMONIA -- likely aspiration in context of esophogeal food
impaction.  Continue antimicrobials, MDIs.  Encourage cough.
HYPOXEMIA -- attributed to pneumonia.  Improving.  Continue
supplimental oxygen, maintain SaO2 > 90%.  Monitor closely.
NAUSEA/VOMITTING -- attributed to food impaction, but now improved.
[**Month (only) 8**] be contribution of severe cough --> vomiting.  Now improving.
ACUTE RENAL FAIULRE -- likely pre-renal. Improve with hydration.
ANEMIA -- falling Hct, without clinical evidence for blood loss.  [**Month (only) 8**]
be dilutional.  Monitor serial Hct, guiac stools.
HYPOTHYROIDISM -- elevated TSH.  Will check free T4

The patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of developmental delay, esophageal stricture, and multiple medical conditions including pneumonia, hypoxemia, nausea/vomiting, acute renal failure, anemia, hypothyroidism, bipolar disorder, and Crohn's disease. The patient was admitted with food impaction and pneumonia. The patient underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to move the food impaction into the stomach. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 140/55 mmHg, respiratory rate of 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on supplemental oxygen. The patient's general appearance is well-nourished, overweight, and not in acute distress. Physical examination findings include normal pupils, no conjunctival pallor or scleral icterus, normocephalic head, no cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, normal heart sounds, symmetric chest expansion, clear breath sounds with no wheezes or crackles, soft and non-tender abdomen, warm extremities, and no skin rash or jaundice. The patient is neurologically attentive and follows simple commands.
